qas.question: Do European Leagues sell their television rights per a collective level?

answers.text: other European Leagues, including La Liga, in which each club sells its rights individually

qas.question: What happens when European Leagues sell their televsion rights individually?

answers.text: a much higher share of the total income going to the top few clubs

qas.question: How is the teleivsion revenue distributed in the Premier League?

answers.text: The money is divided into three parts:

qas.question: How is half of the money distributed?

answers.text: half is divided equally between the clubs

qas.question: How is the final quarter of the money distributed?

answers.text: the final quarter is paid out as facilities fees for games that are shown on television, with the top clubs generally receiving the largest shares of this.

context: The Premier League sells its television rights <b10_0>on a <a5_0>collective basis<b10_0/><a5_0/>. This is in contrast to some <a0_0>other European Leagues, including La Liga, in which each club sells its rights <a6_0><b11_0>individually<b11_0/><a6_0/><a0_0/>, leading to <a1_0>a much higher share of the total income going to <a7_0>the top few clubs<a7_0/><a1_0/>. <a2_0>The money is divided into three parts:<a2_0/> <a3_0><a8_0>half<a8_0/> is divided equally between the clubs<a3_0/>; <a9_0>one quarter<a9_0/> is awarded on a merit basis based on final league position, the top club getting twenty times as much as the bottom club, and equal steps all the way down the table; <a4_0>the final quarter is paid out as facilities fees for games that are shown on television, with the top clubs generally receiving the largest shares of this.<a4_0/> The income from overseas rights is divided <b12_0><b13_0>equally<b13_0/><b12_0/> between the <b14_0>twenty<b14_0/> clubs.
